caption: The original meter stick. Not so obvious to see but it has a lot of meanings behind it. Recommend “Measure of All Things” by Ken Alder. The history of the metric system is very interesting
This marker of one of the original meter sticks is freely accessible via the sidewalk, no construction. It looks great, and for a measurement nerd like myself, a highlight for visit paris.
A very good example of meter. The one and only original in the city.

Five stars for its very existence, but today (early February, 2020), the object is covered up and inside a construction site. I asked the guys working there if I could see it anyway, and they said, non, quelle dommage, impossible. I tried being really pathetic, came from California to see this, no dice. We should be done by end of the month, maybe, one said. Or April, said another. Come back! Anyway, if you think the meter is a cool thing, read “The Measure of All Things,” a dynamite history of the two French surveyors who determined its length. Or did they? The story is full of courage, persistence, ingenuity, war, and madness. And the first international scientific conference. And why the USA does not use the metric system. Spoiler: they didn’t want any help from Thomas Jefferson.
It is interesting that this is one of the last two remaining in Paris and the only one still on its original site. But there was no visitors when I visited.
Contemplate and weep at how this little marble carving changed the world. Do not contemplate and weep if your car gets 40 rods to the hogshead and that's the way you like it.
Incredible historic landmark. Amazing to see the original meter stick!
nice to see when you are near the luxembourg park

The small explanatory plaque deserves your attention: The National Convention, in order to generalize the use of the metric system, had sixteen marble standard meters placed in the most frequented places in Paris These meters were installed between February 1796 and December 1797. This one is one of the last two remaining in Paris and the only one still on its original site. It is rue de Vaugirard near the entrance to the Palais du Luxembourg. Interesting for children with its decimeter and centimeter divisions.

The meter was first defined in 1791, This standard meter is delimited by bronze, It allows us to present the metric system to Parisians, The old measurements referred to the human being, It is the oldest still in its original place, In 1795, the meter was adopted as the official measure of length.
In 1796, the national convention established the metric system and installed 16 marble standard meters in the capital This one is one of the very last ones in its original place

One of the few master meters left in Paris. Initially 16 were installed, of which only two remain today: This one and the one on Place Vendôme. However, this one is in its original location, which is not the case with the other one, which is not even known where it was moved from to its current position.
Place to visit if you are a fan of the history of metrology!
A historical meter. For everyone to take measurements.
Original measurement of 1 meter, apparently in its original original mounting location. A nice point along the way.
At 36 rue de Vaugirard, in the courtyard you will have the pleasant surprise of coming face to face with a magnificent Roman oven exhumed near Luxemburg and stored here
